translated: The Pāṭimokkha of the Theravāda tradition
The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on relinquishment
The sub-chapter on robes🔽1. The training rule on more than that

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū acchinnacīvarake bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vadanti—🔽“bhagavatā, āvuso, anuññātaṁ—
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū acchinna cīvarake bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā evam vadanti  bhagavatā āvuso anuññāta
translated: the monks from the group of six went to monks whose robes had been stolen and said,

original: ‘acchinnacīvarassa vā naṭṭhacīvarassa vā aññātakaṁ gahapatiṁ vā gahapatāniṁ vā cīvaraṁ viññāpetuṁ’;
analyzed: acchinna cīvarassa vā naṭṭha cīvarassa vā aññātakam gahapatim vā gahapatānim vā cīvaram viññāpetu
translated: “The Buddha has laid down a rule that if your robes have been stolen, you may ask an unrelated male or female householder for a robe.
Ask them for a robe.”

original: “Alaṁ, āvuso, laddhaṁ amhehi cīvaran”ti.🔽“Mayaṁ āyasmantānaṁ viññāpemā”ti.
analyzed: ala āvuso laddham amhehi cīvaranti  mayam āyasmantānam viññāpema ati
translated: “We’ve already got a robe.”🔽“We’ll ask for you.”
“Then ask.”

original: Atha kho chabbaggiyā bhikkhū gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ—
analyzed: atha kho chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā etat avocu
translated: The monks from the group of six then went to householders and said,
“Monks whose robes have been stolen have arrived.
Please give them robes.”
And they asked for many robes.

original: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro puriso sabhāyaṁ nisinno aññataraṁ purisaṁ etadavoca—
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena aññataraḥ puriso sabhāyam nisinnaḥ aññataram purisam etat avoca
translated: On one occasion a man said to another man who was sitting in the public meeting hall,
At one time a man was sitting in the public meeting hall when another man said to him, “Venerable, the monks have arrived without robes.

original: Tesaṁ mayā cīvaraṁ dinnan”ti.🔽Sopi evamāha—“mayāpi dinnan”ti.
analyzed: tesam mayā cīvaram dinnanti  saḥ upi
translated: I gave them robe-cloth.”🔽The other man said, “I did too.”
Another man said, “I did too.”
They then complained and criticized those monks,

original: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā na mattaṁ jānitvā bahuṁ cīvaraṁ viññāpessanti,
analyzed: katham hi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyāḥ na mattam jānitvā bahum cīvaram viññāpessanti
translated: “How can the Sakyan monastics ask for many robes without moderation?

original: dussavāṇijjaṁ vā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā karissanti, paggāhikasālaṁ vā pasāressantī”ti.
analyzed: dussa vāṇijjam vā samaṇā sakya puttiyā karissanti paggāhika sālam vā pasāressanti iti
translated: Are the Sakyan monastics going to trade in cloth or set up a shop?”

original: Assosuṁ kho bhikkhū tesaṁ manussānaṁ ujjhāyantānaṁ khiyyantānaṁ vipācentānaṁ.
analyzed: assosum kho bhikkhū tesam manussānam ujjhāyantānam khiyyantānam vipācentāna
translated: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

original: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
analyzed: ye te bhikkhū appicchā pe te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti
translated: and the monks of few desires … criticized those monks,

original: “kathañhi nāma chabbaggiyā bhikkhū na mattaṁ jānitvā bahuṁ cīvaraṁ viññāpessantī”ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū na mattam jānitvā bahum cīvaram viññāpessanti iti
translated: “How can the monks from the group of six ask for many robes without moderation?”

original: Atha kho te bhikkhū chabbaggiye bhikkhū anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ …pe…
analyzed: atha kho te bhikkhū chabbaggiye bhikkhū aneka pariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etam attham ārocesuṃ pe
translated: The monks rebuked the monks from the group of six, “How can you ask for many robes without knowing moderation?” They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and addressed the monks:

original: “saccaṁ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, na mattaṁ jānitvā bahuṁ cīvaraṁ viññāpethā”ti?
analyzed: saccam kira tumhe bhikkhave na mattam jānitvā bahum cīvaram viññāpetha ati
translated: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
“It’s true, Sir.”
The Buddha rebuked them …

original: kathañhi nāma tumhe, moghapurisā, na mattaṁ jānitvā bahuṁ cīvaraṁ viññāpessatha.
analyzed: katham hi nāma tumhe mogha purisāḥ na mattam jānitvā bahum cīvaram viññāpessatha
translated: “Foolish men, how can you ask for many robes without knowing moderation?

analyzed: neta moghapurisāḥ appasannānam vā pasādāya pe
translated: This neither inspires faith in the faithless …”

original: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ uddiseyyātha—🔽“Tañce aññātako gahapati vā gahapatānī vā bahūhi cīvarehi abhihaṭṭhuṁ pavāreyya santaruttaraparamaṁ
analyzed: evam ca pana bhikkhave imam sikkhāpadam uddiseyyātha  tañce aññātakaḥ gahapati vā gahapatānī vā bahūhi cīvarehi abhihaṭṭhum pavāreyya santar uttara parama
translated: And he laid down this training rule:

original: tena bhikkhunā tato cīvaraṁ sāditabbaṁ. Tato ce uttari sādiyeyya, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyan”ti.
analyzed: tena bhikkhunā tatas cīvaram sāditabba tatas ce uttari sādiyeyya nissaggiyam pācittiyan ti
translated: ‘If a lay follower who is not a relation invites a monk to take as much robe-cloth as he needs, the monk may accept robe-cloth from him up to two sets of upper and lower robes. If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”🔽If a lay follower who is not a relation:🔽a lay follower who is not related to the monk on his mother’s or father’s side down to the seventh generation.

analyzed: tat ca iti 🔽a chinna cīvarakam bhikkhu 🔽aññātakaḥ nāma
translated: Not a relation:

original: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddho.
analyzed: mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ vā yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā asambaddhaḥ
translated: He is unrelated if he is unrelated on his mother’s side, his father’s side, or his mother’s or father’s side back to the seventh generation.
A householder:
anyone who lives at home.
A householder’s wife:

analyzed: yā kāci agāram ajjhāvasati  bahūhi cīvarehi iti
translated: anyone who lives with a man.🔽If he has many robes:
if he has many robes.
To take back:
“Take as much as you wish.”

original: Santaruttaraparamaṁ tena bhikkhunā tato cīvaraṁ sāditabbanti
analyzed: santar uttara paramam tena bhikkhunā tatas cīvaram sāditabbanti
translated: The monk should accept a robe from that householder up to the value of two and a half māsaka coins:

original: sace tīṇi naṭṭhāni honti dve sāditabbāni, dve naṭṭhāni ekaṁ sāditabbaṁ, ekaṁ naṭṭhaṁ na kiñci sāditabbaṁ.
analyzed: sace tīṇi naṭṭhāni honti dve sāditabbāni dve naṭṭhāni ekam sāditabbaḥ ekam naṭṭham na kiñci sāditabba
translated: if three robes are lost, he should accept two; if two are lost, he should accept one; if one is lost, he shouldn’t accept anything.

original: Tato ce uttari sādiyeyyāti🔽tatuttari viññāpeti, payoge dukkaṭaṁ.
analyzed: tatas ce uttari sādiyeyyāti  tat uttari viññāpeti payoge dukkaṭa
translated: If he accepts more:🔽if he asks for more, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
When he gets it, the robe must be relinquished.

original: Nissajjitabbaṁ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
analyzed: nissajjitabbam saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā
translated: It should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

original: “idaṁ me, bhante, cīvaraṁ aññātakaṁ gahapatikaṁ upasaṅkamitvā tatuttari viññāpitaṁ nissaggiyaṁ.
analyzed: idam me bhante cīvaram aññātakam gahapatikam upasaṅkamitvā tat uttari viññāpitam nissaggiya
translated: ‘Venerables, this robe that I asked for from an unrelated householder after going to him on my own, and which exceeds the right amount, is to be relinquished.

analyzed: imā aham saṅghassa nissajjāmi iti pe  dadeyyā ati pe
translated: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …🔽‘to give …’ …
‘to give …’ …

original: āyasmato dammīti.🔽Aññātake aññātakasaññī tatuttari cīvaraṁ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.🔽Aññātake vematiko tatuttari cīvaraṁ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ dammi iti  aññātake aññātaka saññī tatuttari cīvaram viññāpeti nissaggiyam pācittiya  aññātake vematiko tatuttari cīvaram viññāpeti nissaggiyam pācittiya
translated: ‘I give it to you.’🔽If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks for more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.🔽If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks for more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

original: Aññātake ñātakasaññī tatuttari cīvaraṁ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṁ pācittiyaṁ.🔽Ñātake aññātakasaññī, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: aññātake ñātaka saññī tatuttari cīvaram viññāpeti nissaggiyam pācittiya  ñātake aññātaka saññī āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks for more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.🔽If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
If the person is related, and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
There is no offense if
he says, “I’ll bring the rest,” and then goes to get it;

original: “sesakaṁ tuyheva hotū”ti denti,🔽na acchinnakāraṇā denti,🔽na naṭṭhakāraṇā denti,
analyzed: sesakam tuyhā iva hotu uti denti  na acchinna kāraṇāḥ denti  na naṭṭha kāraṇāḥ denti
translated: if they give it to him, saying, “It’s yours”;🔽if they give it without asking for anything in return;🔽if they give it because it has been lost;
if they are related;🔽if they are friends;
if he uses his own money;
if he is insane;
one who is a beginner.
A beginner.
